channel.title: Quickchat

item.title: Quickchat
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:26, topic:523708”] public String[] skillNames = { "Attack", "Hitpoints", "Mining", "Strength", "Agility", "Smithing", "Defence", "Herblore", "Fishing", "Ranged", "Thieving", "Cooking", "Prayer", "Crafting", "FireMaking", "Magic", "Fletching", "WoodCuttings", "Runecrafting", "Slayer", "Farming" };

Oh God.

All of you aren’t making this any simpler.

Just make a simple class, and in it make a method with 2 perimeters. 1 Player class instance and 1 String. When the player clicks the skill icon, call that method and describe in the String parimeter the skill’s name.

[hr]

Example:

In ActionButtonPacketHandler (or whatever it is):

case 33206:
	SkillYeller.yell(c, "Attack");
	break;

I know this isn’t even a good way either really, but none of you have suggested anything and made an argument right here.[/quote]I’d rather using my loop, tehehehe

Read full topic

        public String[] skillNames = { "Attack", "Hitpoints", "Mining", "Strength",

                        "Fletching", "WoodCuttings", "Runecrafting", "Slayer", "Farming" };

Oh God.

All of you aren’t making this any simpler.

Just make a simple class, and in it make a method with 2 perimeters. 1 Player class instance and 1 String. When the player clicks the skill icon, call that method and describe in the String parimeter the skill’s name.

[hr]

Example:

In ActionButtonPacketHandler (or whatever it is):

case 33206:
	SkillYeller.yell(c, "Attack");
	break;

I know this isn’t even a good way either really, but none of you have suggested anything and made an argument right here.

item.title: Quickchat
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:19, topic:523708”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=642253.msg4324979#msg4324979 date=1372738650]

[quote author=wildskiller link=topic=642253.msg4324958#msg4324958 date=1372735685]

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=642253.msg4324956#msg4324956 date=1372735349]

I question you because this isn’t even worth being in a class itself.
[/quote]I question you, now. This should very well be in a class of its own.

Not this. Not what he released.
[/quote]And why not?

2 arrays, a method, and some text to be output, tell me why it should be in one?

You shouldn’t just clutter your classes with code that isn’t relative to the class. I do believe this should be in a class of its own. It could be switched around a bit to make it way more useful, or maybe an addition to the quick chat instead of just skills.
[/quote]This. In development - organization is key.

This wouldn’t really be that much clutter.

If you really wanted organization, you’d want all text to be handled under one class, and then called in others.

like all packets (sendframeX), that’d all be one class, as it clutters PA.
What’s the point of PA if not to use key items like that.

Or clickingbuttons if it’s not to handle button clicking

[size=1pt]I’m high so don’t quote me on this[/size][/quote]Just because it isn’t much clutter does not mean you should ignore organization. Small steps count as steps, too.

Read full topic

item.title: Quickchat
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:20, topic:523708”]lol niggas i was messing with polymorphism
and i got this, any criticsm?

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

import server.euthymia.jugador.Client;

public class QuickChat {

Client c;

public QuickChat(){
	
}

public int[] skillInterfaceIds = { 33206, 33207, 33208, 33209, 33210, 33211,
		33212, 33213, 33214, 33215, 33216, 33217, 33218, 33219, 33220,
		33221, 33222, 33223, 33224, 33225, 33226 };

public String[] skillNames = { "Attack", "Hitpoints", "Mining", "Strength",
		"Agility", "Smithing", "Defence", "Herblore", "Fishing", "Ranged",
		"Thieving", "Cooking", "Prayer", "Crafting", "FireMaking", "Magic",
		"Fletching", "WoodCuttings", "Runecrafting", "Slayer", "Farming" };

public void startQuickChat(int actionButtonId, Sender s) {
	s.yell(actionButtonId);
}

}
[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

import server.euthymia.jugador.Client;

public class SkillButtonChat extends QuickChat implements Sender {

public SkillButtonChat(Client client) {
	this.c = client;
}


Client c;

public void yell(int actionButtonId) {
	for (int i = 0; i < skillInterfaceIds.length; i++) {
		if (c.actionButtonId == skillInterfaceIds[i]) {
			c.plrText = "[QC] my " + skillNames[i] + " level is "
					+ c.playerLevel[i] + "";
			c.plrTextUpdateRequired = true;
		}
	}

}

}[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

public interface Sender {

public void yell(int actionButtonId);

}
[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

/*

  • This class will handle the clicking in the quest tab were im willing to put a part of quickchat

  • lol
    */
    public class QuestTabChat extends QuickChat implements Sender {

    @Override
    public void yell(int actionButtonId) {
    // TODO Auto-generated method stub

    }

}
[/code][/quote]
You shouldn’t need an interface for yell. I really can’t find any reason you would need QuickChat to be abstract or Sender to be an interface.

I guess a good example would be:

interface Tool {
	int[][] getRequirements();

	double getSpeed();

	boolean doubleXP();
}

abstract class NPC {
	public abstract boolean canWalk();

	public abstract boolean respawnable();

	public abstract boolean attackable();

	public abstract int getCombatLevel();
}

I usually load abstract classes from a file. They are used for inheriting classes that require the same type of data.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

lol niggas i was messing with polymorphism
and i got this, any criticsm?

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

import server.euthymia.jugador.Client;

public class QuickChat {

Client c;

public QuickChat(){
	
}

public int[] skillInterfaceIds = { 33206, 33207, 33208, 33209, 33210, 33211,
		33212, 33213, 33214, 33215, 33216, 33217, 33218, 33219, 33220,
		33221, 33222, 33223, 33224, 33225, 33226 };

public String[] skillNames = { "Attack", "Hitpoints", "Mining", "Strength",
		"Agility", "Smithing", "Defence", "Herblore", "Fishing", "Ranged",
		"Thieving", "Cooking", "Prayer", "Crafting", "FireMaking", "Magic",
		"Fletching", "WoodCuttings", "Runecrafting", "Slayer", "Farming" };

public void startQuickChat(int actionButtonId, Sender s) {
	s.yell(actionButtonId);
}

}
[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

import server.euthymia.jugador.Client;

public class SkillButtonChat extends QuickChat implements Sender {

public SkillButtonChat(Client client) {
	this.c = client;
}


Client c;

public void yell(int actionButtonId) {
	for (int i = 0; i < skillInterfaceIds.length; i++) {
		if (c.actionButtonId == skillInterfaceIds[i]) {
			c.plrText = "[QC] my " + skillNames[i] + " level is "
					+ c.playerLevel[i] + "";
			c.plrTextUpdateRequired = true;
		}
	}

}

}[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

public interface Sender {

public void yell(int actionButtonId);

}
[/code]

[code]package server.euthymia.jugador.miscellaneous.quickchat;

/*

  • This class will handle the clicking in the quest tab were im willing to put a part of quickchat

  • lol
    */
    public class QuestTabChat extends QuickChat implements Sender {

    @Override
    public void yell(int actionButtonId) {
    // TODO Auto-generated method stub

    }

}
[/code]

item.title: Quickchat
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

DAn0194:

There is already skill names in the client class.

Yeah it’s just a class with an array of names, last I remember.

To be honest, quick chat, in all it’s forms, should be handled client sided, maybe not for the level/xp callouts, but otherwise, yes, it should.

item.title: Quickchat
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:8, topic:523708”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=642253.msg4324867#msg4324867 date=1372722868]

I question you because this isn’t even worth being in a class itself.
You can handle the clicking buttons in an array, and the position of the clicking button in the array would be the same as the skill number.
so 329455 (assume it’s attack’s button) would be 0 in the array.
and so on.
Then you use a single method to set up the chat, and get the right skill name, and done.
[/quote]yea it’s made for an old wl so you know… and about grabbing the skill name i was actually trying to do that but couldn’t so made another array for the names.
Also about making it on its own class it’s with the only purpose of adding more of quickchat later.

Most of these 317 related posts make me think that none of the classes are organized. Does your server not have a skills class that handles experience, skills, etc., or even the skill names?

i have a class called skill wich is extended by all skills and an interface skiller[/quote]

Then it would be useful to have it hold the skill names rather than just adding a new array each time you want to get the skills’ names.

Read full topic
